facts.text: In the 1957 General Elections the appellant was declared elected to the Punjab Legislative Assembly.
Respondent Gian Chand filed Election Petition No. 249 of 1957 before the Election Tribunal, Karnal, for a declaration that the appellant's election was void.
Another unsuccessful candidate was made a party to the election petition but never appeared at any stage.
Shri Harbaksh Singh, Member, Election Tribunal, Karnal, framed a number of issues and recorded evidence in the election petition.

When the case was ready for argument, the appellant applied to the Tribunal for dismissal of the petition under s.90(3) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, on the ground of non-compliance with s.117 (receipt not showing deposit of Rs.1000 in favour of Secretary to the Election Commission).
The respondent objected to the application on grounds of delay and that it could not be decided without evidence.

The Tribunal overruled objections, scrutinized the receipt alone, held it not in terms of s.117, and dismissed the petition under s.90(3) without deciding other issues, by judgment dated November 8, 1957.
Respondent appealed to Punjab High Court in First Appeal Order No. 183 of 1957.
Punjab High Court held appeal lay and Tribunal's order wrong as s.117 complied with, by judgment dated August 12, 1958.
Appellant filed present appeal by special leave against High Court order.

The respondent deposited Rs.1000 and enclosed a Treasury receipt with the petition, which stated: 'By whom tendered- Gian Chand' and 'Name of the person on whose behalf money is paid- Secretary to the Election Commission.'

legal_issues.text: Whether an appeal lay to the High Court from the Election Tribunal's order dismissing the petition under s.90(3) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, or whether such order was not under s.98 and hence not appealable under s.116A.
Whether the Treasury receipt enclosed with the election petition complied with the requirements of s.117 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

petitioner_arguments.text: No appeal lay to High Court as Tribunal's dismissal order was under s.90(3), not under s.98 or s.99; s.98 applies only at conclusion of trial after evidence and arguments, while s.90(3) dismissal is prior thereto.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951: ss.90(3), 98, 99, 116A

petitioner_arguments.text: Revisions of s.85 (Election Commission dismissal, non-appealable) and s.90(3) are substantially same, indicating no appeal under s.90(3).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951: ss.85, 90(3)

petitioner_arguments.text: S.99 requires finding on corrupt practices if alleged, which would be senseless if s.90(3) dismissal deemed under s.98.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951: s.99

petitioner_arguments.text: Treasury receipt did not comply with s.117 as it showed money paid by respondent acting for Secretary, not in favour of Secretary.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951: s.117

respondent_arguments.text: Application to dismiss under s.90(3) should not be entertained due to delay and required evidence.
Terms of s.117 were complied with by the Treasury receipt.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951: s.117

court_reasoning.text: Order under s.90(3) is made at the conclusion of the trial under s.98, as trial encompasses entire proceedings before Tribunal from reference under s.86 to final order; hence appealable under s.116A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sole duty of Tribunal is to try election petition; order closing proceedings is at conclusion of trial.

court_reasoning.text: Provisions like ss.86(4), 88, 89 treat entire proceedings as 'trial'; no restricted meaning to 'trial' in s.98.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of Chapter III (ss.86-107) covers entire trial from reference to final order.

court_reasoning.text: Ss.103, 106, 107 apply to s.98 orders; no reason to treat s.90(3) dismissals differently; s.90(3) states power, s.98 the form of order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Practical result of dismissal same whether on merits or preliminary ground.

court_reasoning.text: S.99 argument unpersuasive; if construction requires finding on corrupt practices even in s.90(3) dismissal, it must prevail; s.99(1)(b) implies costs order under s.98.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Harihar Singh v. Singh Ganga Prasad wrongly decided.

court_reasoning.text: Treasury receipt complies with s.117; 'Name of the person on whose behalf money is paid- Secretary to the Election Commission' indicates person in whose favour paid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot read receipt as money paid by petitioner acting for Secretary.

holdings.text: Order dismissing election petition under s.90(3) for non-compliance with ss.81,82 or 117 is an order under s.98 made at conclusion of trial, appealable to High Court under s.116A.
The Treasury receipt enclosed with the petition was in terms of s.117.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harish Chandra Bajpai v. Triloki Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Trial' in s.90(2) means entire proceedings before Tribunal, supporting wider meaning in s.98.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. Kamaraja Nadar v. Kunju Thevar
precedents_cited.relevance: Described s.90(3) objection as preliminary, directed decision first to save costs, but not on appealability or timing of order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harihar Singh v. Singh Ganga Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: Took contrary view that s.90(3) order not under s.98; wrongly decided.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs procedure for election petitions, dismissal for non-compliance, appealability, and form of Tribunal orders; s.90(3) dismissal under s.98 and appealable; s.117 receipt compliant.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that appeal lay to High Court from Tribunal's s.90(3) order (as under s.98) and that the Treasury receipt complied with s.117, affirming High Court's reversal of Tribunal's dismissal.
outcome.relief_granted: Election petition not dismissed; proceeds on merits.

key_quotes.text: "An order made under the powers contained in s.90(3) brings to an end the proceedings arising out of a petition after it is made, nothing more remains for the Election Tribunal to try or do in respect of that petition."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines s.90(3) order as at conclusion of trial under s.98.

key_quotes.text: "The second of the two entries reproduced above is intended to indicate the person in whose favour the money has been paid on whose behalf here clearly indicates in whose favour or for whose benefit."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets Treasury receipt as compliant with s.117.
